Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Structure-property-processing Relations for Aggregation-resistant Graphene

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to test the broad hypothesis that graphene may be rendered aggregation-resistant by simultaneous exfoliation and non-covalent functionalization. This would facilitate use in a range of promising bulk material applications, and this would substantially improve upon existing graphene production techniques, which suffer from a range of problems (small-scale, compromising properties via defect generation, aggregation). This project will address these critical challenges through a number of research thrusts. These include (1) combining bulk intercalation techniques with stabilizer solutions, (2) the post-processing of dispersed pristine graphene to induce novel, aggregation-resistant morphologies, and (3) investigation of processing effects on graphene performance in conductive, low density composites and monoliths.

If successful, the results of this research will yield techniques that are orders-of-magnitude more effective than prior methods in processing stabilized graphene. The proposed project also provides insight into how the processing technique (exfoliation, stabilization, spray drying) determines the structure (chemical functionality, surface coverage, morphology) and hence the properties (aggregation resistance, gas barrier, electrical percolation, composite enhancement). The development of scalable processing for pristine graphene is relevant to a wide range of multifunctional industrial materials including aerospace structural composites, sensors, supercapacitors, and flame-retardant textiles. The multifaceted educational plan includes (1) graduate, undergraduate, and high school student mentorship, (2) a new program designed to encourage engineers to pursue graduate studies, and (3) an expansion of the PI?s successful ?Science and Science Fiction? outreach course that aims to increase STEM interest at local high schools.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant aims to develop scalable techniques for processing graphene from graphite and to develop the science that connects this processing with the resulting graphene morphology, structure, and material properties. This CAREER award has resulted in a number of fundamental advances in the area of graphene nanosheet processing, with an extraordinary number of publications and scientific insight supported by the grant:

-          In the main thrust of the proposal, we demonstrated how unconventional dispersants (pyrenes, quantum dots, photo-degradable or magnetic-tethered polymers, pyrene-terminated polymers), co-solvent systems, and ionic liquids can be used to create stable, high-concentration dispersions of graphene and other nanosheets. We also measured to what degree dispersants can or cannot be removed from the as-produced nanosheets.

-          We discovered that the interplay between diffusion and capillary forces during spray drying can be used to create crumpled 3D nanoparticles from 2D nanosheet dispersions (Figure 1); this is useful for a number of applications, including energy storage electrodes.

-          As a result of the advances from this grant, we were invited to write a definitive review of pristine graphene processing science (published in Advanced Materials in 2016, Figure 2) and showed how chemical engineering principles of separation can be applied to graphene recovery.

-          We demonstrated that both graphene and graphene oxide can be manipulated to create 3D hydrogels (Figure 3) and aerogels with varying degrees of porosity and stiffness.

-          We invented a new, patented technique for producing graphene using electrochemical exfoliation of graphite in a compressed, expandable membrane. This method is particularly exciting because it allows for high yields and is potentially scalable to high production rates (Figure 4).

-          In the last phase of the grant, we have also examined the topic of safety surrounding graphene family nanomaterials, both in the synthesis process and in the final material.

This award has resulted in 20 publications and one major patent over six years. This has prompted new collaborations between the PI's group and several major industrial companies. In addition to graduate student training, multiple undergraduate researchers were trained in nanomaterials processing, with five different undergraduate researchers publishing first-author papers.

In addition, this award supported outreach efforts in two major thrusts: (1) The PI has given presentations on "Graduate School Mythbusters" to numerous undergraduate groups (including historically underrepresented minority student groups) to show how graduate school in engineering works and that it can be financially workable and lead to rewarding careers. (2) Each year, the PI has given a "Science and Science Fiction" short course in local Texas high schools to help students think through technology and ethics in an exciting way that will increase STEM participation.

Modified by: Micah J Green

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This grant aims to develop scalable techniques for processing graphene from graphite and to develop the science that connects this processing with the resulting graphene morphology, structure, and material properties. This CAREER award has resulted in a number of fundamental advances in the area of graphene nanosheet processing, with an extraordinary number of publications and scientific insight supported by the grant: - In the main thrust of the proposal, we demonstrated how unconventional dispersants (pyrenes, quantum dots, photo-degradable or magnetic-tethered polymers, pyrene-terminated polymers), co-solvent systems, and ionic liquids can be used to create stable, high-concentration dispersions of graphene and other nanosheets. We also measured to what degree dispersants can or cannot be removed from the as-produced nanosheets. - We discovered that the interplay between diffusion and capillary forces during spray drying can be used to create crumpled 3D nanoparticles from 2D nanosheet dispersions (Figure 1); this is useful for a number of applications, including energy storage electrodes. - As a result of the advances from this grant, we were invited to write a definitive review of pristine graphene processing science (published in Advanced Materials in 2016, Figure 2) and showed how chemical engineering principles of separation can be applied to graphene recovery. - We demonstrated that both graphene and graphene oxide can be manipulated to create 3D hydrogels (Figure 3) and aerogels with varying degrees of porosity and stiffness. - We invented a new, patented technique for producing graphene using electrochemical exfoliation of graphite in a compressed, expandable membrane. This method is particularly exciting because it allows for high yields and is potentially scalable to high production rates (Figure 4). - In the last phase of the grant, we have also examined the topic of safety surrounding graphene family nanomaterials, both in the synthesis process and in the final material. This award has resulted in 20 publications and one major patent over six years. This has prompted new collaborations between the PI's group and several major industrial companies. In addition to graduate student training, multiple undergraduate researchers were trained in nanomaterials processing, with five different undergraduate researchers publishing first-author papers. In addition, this award supported outreach efforts in two major thrusts: (1) The PI has given presentations on "Graduate School Mythbusters" to numerous undergraduate groups (including historically underrepresented minority student groups) to show how graduate school in engineering works and that it can be financially workable and lead to rewarding careers. (2) Each year, the PI has given a "Science and Science Fiction" short course in local Texas high schools to help students think through technology and ethics in an exciting way that will increase STEM participation.
